choices.text: The presence of S3 is abnormal
The systolic murmur is unusual in a pregnant woman at term
The combination of a prominent S3 and an elevated JVP is suggestive of an underlying heart disease
All findings are normal changes of pregnancy

questions.text: The cardiovascular examination of a 21 y primigravida at term reveals a split S1, normal S2, S3 easily audible with a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur greater during inspiration and a mildly elevated JVP. You immediately recognize that:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All findings are normal changes of pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The prevalence of S3 is abnormal: S3 is due to rapid diastolic filling and can be heard in pregnancy

 

Option B: The presence of an ejection systolic murmur is normal in pregnancy due to an increased blood flow.

 

Option C: Both an S3 and a raised JVP can be normal findings in pregnancy

While these signs might suggest heart failure in a non-pregnant individual, during pregnancy, they are typically physiological

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal cardiovascular findings in pregnancy are:

 

On Examination:

 

  • Apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space; 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  • PR increases
  • Mildly elevated JVP
  • (JVP usually remains unchanged in pregnancy, but a borderline elevation without symptoms may still be considered normal)
  • Ejection Systolic murmur at apical/pulmonary area (grade 1/2)
  • Rarely (20%): A soft diastolic murmur may be heard
  • Mammary murmur – left 2nd and 3rd intercostal space – due to increased flow in the internal mammary vessels.
  • S3 – due to rapid diastolic filling
  • S4 – rare
  • ECG – normal pattern; sometimes left axis deviation.

 

It is important to distinguish between pathological findings and normal physiological adaptations during pregnancy to avoid misdiagnosis

 

Ref: Page no 61, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Hemodynamic changes regress to normal after................. weeks of delivery:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 6

 

Explanation:

 

  • Cardiac output returns to normal 2 weeks after delivery
  • Hemodynamic changes completely regress to normal by 42 days (= 6 weeks) post-partum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiac output returns to normal 2 weeks after delivery
  • Hemodynamic changes completely regress to normal by 42 days (= 6 weeks) post-partum.

 

Ref: Page no 57-58, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Monitor her for 24 h with a Holter monitor to rule out an arrhythmia
Do an arterial blood gas analysis
Reassure her that nothing is wrong with her and encourage her not to lie flat on her back

questions.text: A healthy 25 y G1 at 40 weeks gestational age comes for a routine antenatal visit. The patient complains that on several occasions she has experienced dizziness, light headedness and feeling as if she is going to pass out when she lies down on her back to take a nap. What is the appropriate plan of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Reassure her that nothing is wrong with her and encourage her not to lie flat on her back

 

Explanation:

 

The above scenario is of supine hypotension syndrome.

 

  • Seen in 3rd trimester
  • Pressure of gravid uterus on the IVC in supine position
  • Hypotension, tachycardia and syncope
  • Patient is asked to lie on one side and not on her back
  • It is especially dangerous during caesarean where spinal anaesthesia causes hypotension. Hence a left lateral tilt needs to be given.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine Hypotension Syndrome:

 

  • Seen in 3rd trimester.
  • Pressure of gravid uterus on the IVC in supine position.
  • Hypotension, tachycardia and syncope.
  • Patient is asked to lie on one side and not on her back.
  • It is especially dangerous during caesarean where spinal anaesthesia causes hypotension. Hence a left lateral tilt needs to be given.

 

Ref: Page no 60, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Increases by 30-60% of nonpregnant volume
Increases with gestational age and plateaus at 34 weeks
Increase is less with low-normal range hematocrit and more with high normal range hematocrit
Increase is 40-80% with multifetal gestation

questions.text: What is not true about blood volume in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Increase is less with low-normal range hematocrit and more with high normal range hematocrit

 

Explanation:

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Blood volume increases by 30-60% of nonpregnant volume. This is correct.
  • Option B: Blood Increases with gestational age and plateaus at 34 weeks.
  • Option C: The increase in blood volume in pregnancy is more with low-normal range hematocrit and less with high normal range hematocrit
  • Option D: The increase in blood volume is 40-80% with multifetal gestation   

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regarding blood volume in pregnancy:

 

  • Increased vascularity of the enlarging uterus with the interposition of uteroplacental circulation
  • Blood volume raised: 40 – 50%
  • Starts in the 6th weeks; maximum at 34 weeks – then remains static.
  • Higher in multigravida, multiple pregnancy and large babies.

 

Ref: Page no 57, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Slight increase in the systolic and diastolic left ventricular dimensions
Moderate increase in the size of the right atrium
Moderate increase in the size of the right ventricle
Moderate decrease in the size of the left atrium

questions.text: Normal echocardiographic changes in pregnancy include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Moderate decrease in the size of the left atrium

 

Explanation:

 

In Echocardiography in pregnancy there is chamber enlargement of all 4 chambers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Echo changes in pregnancy
    • Physiologic multivalvular regurgitation (Rt > Left)
    • Chamber enlargement (all 4 chambers) – secondary to hypervolemia
    • Valvular annular dilatation
    • Small asymptomatic pericardial effusion

 

Ref: Page no 2346-7, Hurst’s The Heart 14th edition

questions.text: The total amount of iron required during pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1000 mg

 

Explanation:

 

  • Total iron requirement in pregnancy is 1000 mg
    • 500 mg – red cell mass expansion
    • 300 mg – placenta and fetus
    • 200 mg – shed through skin/ GIT/ renal

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Total iron requirement in pregnancy is 1000 mg
    • 500 mg – red cell mass expansion
    • 300 mg – placenta and fetus
    • 200 mg – shed through skin/ GIT/ renal

 

Ref: Page no 58, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Rise in total leucocyte count
Decrease in the peripheral resistance by 50%
Rise in cardiac output by 70%

questions.text: Physiological changes in pregnancy includes all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rise in Hemoglobin

 

Explanation:

Option B: Hb falls in pregnancy due to haemodilution resulting from an unequal increase in blood volume and red cell mass.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Rise in TLC: This is normally seen in pregnancy
  • Option C: The peripheral resistance decreases by 50%
  • Option D: Rise in cardiac output by 70% is normal in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hb falls in pregnancy due to haemodilution resulting from an unequal increase in blood volume and red cell mass.

 

Ref: Page no 57-59, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a normal physiological change during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Increased functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options:

 

Option C: Functional residual capacity is decreased in pregnancy (as the diaphragm is pushed up).

 

Option D: Total protein is decreased. due to hemodilution.

 

Additionally, hemoglobin concentration decreases as plasma volume expands more than red cell mass.

 

Option A: GFR and renal plasma flow are increased.

 

Option B: Cardiac output is increased.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Functional residual capacity  is decreased in pregnancy (as the diaphragm is pushed up).

 

Ref: Page no 58-62 Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Mean pH of vagina during pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 4

 

Explanation:

 

Vagina

 

  • Acidic pH (3.5 – 6): due to conversion of glycogen into lactic acid by the Lactobacillus acidophilus (due to high estrogen level)

 

Educational Objective:
 

 

Ref: Page no 52, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 23y presents at 6 weeks pregnancy with mild spotting. An ultrasound shows a single live fetus corresponding to 6 weeks. You explain that this could be implantation bleed. This is also known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hartman's sign

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hartman’s sign is also known as placental sign
  • It is bleeding on the expected date of the period and is due to implantation of the embryo

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Arias Stella reaction: The Arias-Stella reaction is a histopathological feature in which there is hormone-related atypical endometrial change characterized by hypertrophy and vacuolization of glandular epithelial cells, associated with marked nuclear pleomorphism, enlargement, and hyperchromasia.

 

Option C: Hofman sign: The Hoffman sign is an involuntary flexion movement of the thumb and or index finger when the examiner flicks the fingernail of the middle finger down. The reflexive pathway causes the thumb to flex and adduct quickly. A positive Hoffman sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion and corticospinal pathway dysfunction likely due to cervical cord compression.

 

Option D: Reinz sign: There is no such sign

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hartman’s sign is also known as placental sign
  • It is bleeding on the expected date of the period and is due to implantation of the embryo

 

Ref: Page 61; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

questions.text: Which amongst the following is NOT seen in normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increase in systolic blood pressure 

 

  • Reduction in diastolic BP more than systolic; There is a decrease in diastolic BP and mean arterial pressure by 5-10 mmHg; maximum fall in the 2nd trimester.
  • In normal pregnancy, systemic vascular resistance decreases due to hormonal effects and placental circulation. As a result, blood pressure either remains unchanged or decreases slightly, despite an increase in cardiac output.
  • (Systolic blood pressure remains the same or slightly decreases, while diastolic blood pressure decreases more, especially in the second trimester)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Increase in heart rate; This is normally seen in pregnancy; the heart rate generally increases by 10-15bpm

 

Option C: The cardiac output increases by 30-50% in pregnancy

 

Option D: The blood volume increases by 40-60% in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Systemic vascular resistance decreases - reduction in BP
  • Reduction in diastolic BP more than systolic
  • Overall decrease in diastolic BP and mean arterial pressure by 5-10 mmHg
  • Maximum fall in the 2nd trimester
  • No change in central venous pressure and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure

 

Ref: Page no 60, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Softening of lower uterine segment on bimanual examination is known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hegar's Sign 

 

Explanation:

 

  • Softening of lower uterine segment on bimanual examination is known as Hegar’s sign, in early pregnancy (typically by 6–8 weeks of gestation)
  • It is one of the classic named pelvic signs of early pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Named Pelvic signs

 

 

Ref: Page 61; DDC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

questions.text: Crying of fetus in utero is called as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vagitus uterinus 

 

Explanation:

 

The cry of a fetus in utero is known as vagitus uterinus

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cry of a fetus in utero is known as vagitus uterinus

 

Ref: Gingras JL, Mitchell EA, Grattan KE; Fetal homologue of infant crying. Archives of Disease in Childhood - Fetal and Neonatal Edition 2005; 90:F415-F418.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36-week of gestation is admitted in your ward. During the morning rounds, she is lying supine as shown in the figure. What syndrome has been depicted below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Supine vena cava syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Supine hypotension syndrome/ Supine vena cava syndrome

 

(Can be loosely also known as inferior vena cava syndrome but not a standard term)

 

  • Seen in 3rd trimester
  • Pressure of gravid uterus on the IVC in supine position
  • Hypotension, tachycardia and syncope
  • Especially dangerous during cesarean where spinal anesthesia causes hypotension. Hence a left lateral position needs to be given to prevent hypotension (wedge under right hip )

 

Postural Hypotension (Orthostatic Hypotension)

 

Postural hypotension, also called orthostatic hypotension, is defined as a drop in blood pressure upon standing, due to failure of the autonomic nervous system to compensate for gravitational shifts in blood volume. it is not associated with pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior vena cava syndrome: Caused by mediastinal mass or tumor, not pregnancy

 

Option C. Abdominal aorta syndrome: Not a recognized obstetric condition

 

Option D. Postural Hypotension syndrome: Occurs on standing up due to autonomic dysfunction — not due to lying supine or IVC compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Supine hypotension syndrome/ Supine vena cava syndrome

 

  • Seen in 3rd trimester
  • Pressure of gravid uterus on the IVC in supine position
  • Hypotension, tachycardia and syncope
  • Especially dangerous during cesarean where spinal anesthesia causes hypotension. Hence a left lateral position needs to be given to prevent hypotension (wedge under right hip)

 

Ref: Page no 62 - 63, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: ESR increases in pregnancy because of increase in?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fibrinogen

 

Explanation

 

  • ESR in pregnancy is increased 4 – fold. This is due to increased fibrinogen levels

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ESR in pregnancy is increased 4 – fold. This is due to increased fibrinogen levels

 

Ref: Page no 59, Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is true, but the reason is false
The assertion is false but reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: To define anemia in pregnancy, high cutoff of Hb is taken than the non-pregnant scenarios.

 

Reason: Physiological hemodilution is seen in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The assertion is false but reason is true

 

Explanation

 

  • In pregnancy, there is a disproportionate increase in plasma (50%) compared to the RBC volume (20%)
  • This produces a state of hemodilution during pregnancy
  • This reflects as a fall in Hb by about 2g% leading to physiological anemia

 

Hence the assertion that to define anemia in pregnancy, high cutoff of Hb is taken than the non-pregnant scenarios is false as we take a lower cut off in pregnancy

 

The reason is true i.e. physiological hemodilution is seen in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnancy, there is a disproportionate increase in plasma (50%) compared to the RBC volume (20%).
  • This produces a state of hemodilution during pregnancy.
  • This reflects as a fall in Hb by about 2g% leading to physiological anemia.

 

Ref: Page no 58, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Total lung capacity increases by approximately 5 % by term

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding physiological changes in respiratory system in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. FRC decreases

 

  • The functional residual capacity in pregnancy reduces due to upward displacement of the diaphragm

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Minute ventilation does not decrease; it increases by 40% in pregnancy
  • Option B: Reserve volume is decreased in pregnancy (not increased)
  • Option D: Total lung capacity remains unaffected or slightly decreases by about 5% in pregnancy (it does not increase)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 65, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Supine with wedge under right hip

questions.text: A pregnant female presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is taken for cesarean section what is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on OT table?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Supine with wedge under right hip

 

Explanation

 

Supine hypotension syndrome/ Supine vena cava syndrome

 

  • Seen in 3rd trimester
  • Pressure of gravid uterus on the IVC in supine position
  • Hypotension, tachycardia and syncope

 

This is especially dangerous during cesarean where spinal anesthesia causes hypotension. Hence a left tilt needs to be given to prevent hypotension.

 

The goal is to tilt the uterus to the left to relieve pressure on the inferior vena cava (IVC).

 

To achieve this, we place a wedge under the right hip — which tilts the patient slightly to the left.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supine hypotension syndrome/ Supine vena cava syndrome

 

  • Seen in 3rd trimester
  • Pressure of gravid uterus on the IVC in supine position
  • Hypotension, tachycardia and syncope

 

This is especially dangerous during cesarean where spinal anesthesia causes hypotension. Hence a left tilt needs to be given to prevent hypotension

 

Ref: Page no 62-63, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: During pregnancy pulmonary volumes and capacities change from the non-pregnant state. Which of these remains unchanged?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Vital capacity

 

The vital capacity remains unchanged In pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • The functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.
  • The residual volume decreases in pregnancy (due to upward displacement of the diaphragm by the gravid uterus)
  • The tidal volume increases in pregnancy (To meet higher oxygen demands)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory function in pregnancy:  

 

 

Ref: Page no 64, Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition

questions.text: Which of the following indices of respiration decreases in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Residual volume

 

Explanation

 

The residual volume decreases in pregnancy

 

Other options:

 

  • The respiratory rate does not change in pregnancy.
  • The tidal volume increases in pregnancy.
  • The vital capacity remains unchanged in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory function in pregnancy

 

 

Ref: Page no 64-65, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Increase in ventricular stroke volume
Increase in systemic vascular resistance
Cardiac output is higher in lateral recumbent than supine position

questions.text: All are true about hemodynamic changes in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in systemic vascular resistance

 

Explanation:

 

  • Systemic vascular resistance is reduced in pregnancy thereby causing a fall in BP

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Increase in ventricular stroke volume: The stroke volume is increased in pregnancy
  • Option C: Cardiac output is higher in lateral recumbent than supine position: This is because in supine position there is compression of the aorta and the IVC
  • Option D: Increase in heart rate: The heart rate increases in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Systemic vascular resistance is reduced in pregnancy thereby causing a fall in BP

 

Ref: Page 58, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: In pregnancy, the diaphragm is pushed up at term by an average of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 4 cm

 

  • In pregnancy, the diaphragm is pushed up at term by an average of 4 cm due to enlarged gravida uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anatomical changes in Respiratory System in Pregnancy

 

  • Lower ribs flare out
  • Widening of subcostal angle (68° to 102°)
  • Thoracic cage transverse diameter: increases by 2cm
  • Thoracic cage circumference: increases by 6 cm:
  • Diaphragm: rises by 4 cm

 

Ref: Page no 64, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Thoracic cage diameter increases by 2cm

questions.text: All are anatomical changes seen in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Narrowing of subcostal angle

 

Explanation:

 

In pregnancy, there is widening of the sub-costal angle (68° to 102°)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anatomical changes in Respiratory System in Pregnancy

 

  • Lower ribs flare out
  • Widening of subcostal angle (68° to 102°)
  • Thoracic cage transverse diameter: increases by 2cm
  • Thoracic cage circumference: increases by 6 cm:
  • Diaphragm: rises by 4 cm

 

Ref: Page no 64, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Left ureteric dilatation more than right ureteric dilatation
Decreased renal re-absorption of amnio acids
Decreased renal re-absorption of glucose

questions.text: All the below are physiological changes in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left ureteric dilatation more than right ureteric dilatation

 

Explanation:

 In pregnancy, there is right ureteric dilatation is more than left (due to dextro-rotation of the uterus and the right ovarian vein crossing over the right ureter)

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Renal pelvis enlargement: mild pelvicalyceal enlargement of the kidneys is normally seen in pregnancy due to pressure of the gravid uterus
  • Option C and D: In pregnancy, there is decreased renal reabsorption of:
    • Glucose
    • Amino acids
    • Uric acid
    • Water soluble vitamins

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnancy, there is right ureteric dilatation is more than left (due to dextro-rotation of the uterus and the right ovarian vein crossing over the right ureter)

 

Ref: Page no 65-66, Willliams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 25 y primigravid woman presents to the OPD at 8 weeks pregnancy. Her BMI is 27. She asks you what is the average weight gain she needs to gain in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 7-11 kg

 

Explanation:

 

As this patient is overweight (BMI is 27), her average weight gain should be lesser than normal i.e. 7-11kg

 

Educational Objective:

 

The table below shows the ideal weight gain on pregnancy based on a patient’s pre-pregnancy BMI

 

Ideal Weight Gain in Pregnancy

 

 

Ref: Page no 170, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: All the following clotting factors are increased in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Factor XIII

 

  • Factor XIII decreases in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Explanation

 

  • Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state
  • Fibrinogen level: raised by 50% (200-400 mg/ dl to 300-600 mg/dl)
  • ESR increased 4-fold
  • Platelet count: there may be a slight fall
    • Gestational thrombocytopenia due to hemodilution and increased platelet consumption
    • No adverse effect on pregnancy
    • Usually seen in the 3rd trimester
  • Increase in plasma levels of Factors: 1, 2, 7, 8, 9, 10
  • Plasma levels of 2, 5 12 – unchanged/ mildly increased
  • Factors 11, 13 – slightly decreased
  • Clotting time: unaffected

 

Ref: Page no 59 -60, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Estrogen and progesterone is first two months of pregnancy are produced by?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Corpus luteum

 

  • In the initial few weeks—the main source of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy is corpus luteum.
  • This function is gradually taken over by the placenta by 10-12 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the initial few weeks—the main source of estrogen and progesterone during pregnancy is corpus luteum.
  • This function is gradually taken over by the placenta by 10-12 weeks

 

Ref: Page no 230, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Rise in the venous pressure in the lower limb in supine position

questions.text: All of the following occur in pregnancy EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Decrease in fibrinogen levels

 Decrease in fibrinogen levels. This is incorrect. In pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase.

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Increase in Cardiac output: This is a normal finding in pregnancy
  • Option B: Increase in stroke volume: This is also a normal finding in pregnancy
  • Option D: Rise in the venous pressure in the lower limb in supine position: This is also a normal finding in pregnancy; This is because in supine position, the Inferior vena cava is compressed, so the venous pressure in the lower limbs will increase

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Physiological changes associated with pregnancy:
    • Blood volume increases progressively from 6-8 weeks gestation (pregnancy) and reaches a maximum at approximately 32-34 weeks with little change thereafter.
    • Renal plasma flow and glomerular filtration rate begin to increase progressively during the first trimester.
    • Increases in blood volume and cardiac output.
    • Elevations in plasma flow and glomerular filtration result in an elevation in creatinine clearance.
    • Blood urea and serum creatinine are reduced by 40%.
    • Here is also an increase in filtered sodium, but tubular absorption is increased by an increase in aldosterone secretion, via the renin-angiotensin mechanism.
    • There is also a decrease in plasma osmolarity.
       
  • RBC & Haemoglobin:
    • RBC volume is increased to the extent of 20-30%.
    • Total increase in volume is about 350ml; the amount to be regulated by the increased demand of oxygen transport during pregnancy.
    • Disproportionate increase in plasma and RBC volume produces a state of haemodilution during pregnancy.
    • Thus, even though the total haemoglobin mass increases during pregnancy to the extent of 18-20 percent, there is apparent fall in haemoglobin concentration.
    • At term the fall is about 2 gms from the non-pregnant value.
    • There is simultaneous fall in number of red cells by 15-20% and the hematocrit level.

 

Ref: Page no 60, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The presence of the S3 is abnormal
The systolic ejection murmur is unusual in a pregnant woman at term
The combination of a prominent S3 and soft diastolic murmur is a significant abnormality
All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy

questions.text: You are called in to evaluate the heart of a 19-year-old primigravida at term. Listening carefully to the heart, you determine that there is a split S1, normal S2, S3 easily audible with a 2/6 systolic ejection murmur greater during inspiration, and a soft diastolic murmur. You immediately recognize which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. All findings recorded are normal changes in pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: The prevalence of S3 is abnormal: S3 is due to rapid diastolic filling and can be heard in pregnancy
  • Option B: The presence of an ejection systolic murmur is normal in pregnancy due to an increased blood flow.
  • Option C: Both a S3 and a raised JVP can be normal findings in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal cardiovascular findings in pregnancy are:

 

Recognize that split S1, S3, soft systolic murmur, and soft diastolic murmur can all be normal in pregnancy due to physiological cardiovascular adaptations.

 

On Examination:

 

  • Apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space; 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  • PR increases
  • Mildly elevated JVP
  • Ejection Systolic murmur at apical/pulmonary area (grade 1/2)
  • Rarely (20%): A soft diastolic murmur may be heard
  • Mammary murmur – left 2nd and 3rd intercostal space – due to increased flow in the internal mammary vessels.
  • S3 – due to rapid diastolic filling
  • S4 – rare
  • ECG – normal pattern; sometimes left axis deviation.

 

Ref: Page no 61, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is primarily secreted by fetal adrenal cortex?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. DHEAS

 

  • DHEAS is primarily secreted by the fetal adrenal cortex

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetoplacental Unit

 

  • The fetus and the placenta interact in the formation of steroid hormones.
  • The placenta synthesizes pregnenolone and progesterone from cholesterol.
  • Some of the progesterone enters the fetal circulation and provides the substrate for the formation of cortisol and corticosterone in the fetal adrenal glands.
  •  Some of the pregnenolone enters the fetus and, along with pregnenolone synthesized in the fetal liver, is the substrate for the formation of dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and 16-hydroxydehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (16-OHDHEAS) in the fetal adrenal.
  • Some 16-hydroxylation also occurs in the fetal liver. DHEAS and 16-OHDHEAS are transported back to the placenta, where DHEAS forms estradiol and 16-OHDHEAS forms estriol.
  • The principal estrogen formed is estriol, and since fetal 16-OHDHEAS is the principal substrate for the estrogens, the urinary estriol excretion of the mother can be monitored as an index of the state of the fetus.

 

 

Ref: Page 281, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 28 weeks’ gestation, who had normal haemoglobin level 4 weeks ago at her first prenatal visit, complains of 1 week of fatigue and now has a haemoglobin level of 7.0 g/ dL. She noted dark-coloured urine after taking an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. G6PD deficiency anemia

 

  • This 29-year-old woman at 28 weeks’ gestation complains of fatigue. She took an antibiotic for a urinary tract infection and then developed dark-coloured urine. She was also probably icteric. Currently, her haemoglobin level is low, reflecting anemia.
  • This constellation of symptoms likely reflects a haemolytic process probably due to G6PD deficiency. The dark urine suggests bilirubinuria.
  • G6PD deficiency results in increased sensitivity to drug induced haemolysis on intake of oxidant drugs.
  • Other causes of haemolysis could include malaria, HELLP syndrome, autoimmune hemolytic anemia, or sickle cell crisis. In this case, the woman ingested an antibiotic, which likely was nitrofurantoin, a commonly prescribed medication for pregnant women. She does not have hypertension, symptoms of systemic lupus erythematosus or other autoimmune diseases, or pain suggestive of sickle cell disease.

 

Other options:

 

  • Iron deficiency anaemia (microcytic hypochromic) and vitamin B12 deficiency (Macrocytic) are nutritional anaemia not associated with haemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • G6PD deficiency results in increased sensitivity to drug induced haemolysis on intake of oxidant drugs. This can be seen in pregnancy also.

 

Ref: Page 2739, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Carrier protein for estrogen and progesterone
Helps in maintenance of placenta
Maintains colloid osmotic pressure in maternal blood

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of pregnancy associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immunosuppression against fetal antigens

 

  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) largest of the pregnancy associated proteins is produced by both the embryo and the placenta (syncytio-cytotrophoblasts) during pregnancy.
  • This protein is thought to have several different functions, including preventing recognition of the fetus by the maternal immune system, matrix mineralization and angiogenesis.
  • Levels of PAPP-A rise from first detection in the first trimester until term.
  • Maternal serum concentrations are related to subsequent fetal growth and this relationship has suggested that it can be used as a diagnostic test for adverse pregnancy outcomes (intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, preeclampsia, and stillbirth).

 

Maternal serum level of PAPP-A:

 

  • Decreased PAPP-A indicate increased risk of trisomy 21 and trisomy 18
  • First trimester low PAPP-A (< 0.4 MoM) associated with an increased frequency of adverse obstetrical outcomes like Fetal growth restriction, pre-eclampsia, abruption, and intrauterine death

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) largest of the pregnancy associated proteins is produced by both the embryo and the placenta (syncytio-cytotrophoblasts) during pregnancy.
  • This protein is thought to have several different functions, including preventing recognition of the fetus by the maternal immune system, matrix mineralization and angiogenesis.
  • Levels of PAPP-A rise from first detection in the first trimester until term.
  • Maternal serum concentrations are related to subsequent fetal growth and this relationship has suggested that it can be used as a diagnostic test for adverse pregnancy outcomes (intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, preeclampsia, and stillbirth).

 

Ref: Page no 863, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is primarily responsible for the physiological increase in maternal insulin resistance during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Progesterone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Progesterone is the hormone primarily responsible for the physiological increase in maternal insulin resistance during pregnancy. This resistance helps divert glucose to the developing fetus, ensuring an adequate energy supply. The combination of elevated progesterone and other hormones like human placental lactogen contributes to this insulin resistance.

 

Educational Objective: Pregnancy is a diabetogenic state

 

  • There is hyperinsulinemia due to hypertrophy/ hyperplasia of beta cells of pancreas.
  • However, despite this, there is postprandial hyperglycemia due to peripheral insulin resistance mediated primarily by progesterone and also by estrogen, cortisol and hPL.
  • There is also mild fasting hypoglycemia.
  • There is no change in plasma glucagon levels.

 

Ref: Page No 56, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents with lower extremity edema. She is concerned about the swelling and asks the physician about the reason for this condition. Which of the following physiological changes in pregnancy primarily contributes to peripheral edema?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increased capillary permeability

 

  • The primary physiological change in pregnancy contributing to peripheral edema is increased capillary permeability. Hormones like progesterone and estrogen cause the dilation of small blood vessels and increased capillary permeability. This allows for the escape of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space, leading to edema, particularly in the lower extremities.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Increased aldosterone level: This leads to increased blood volume and helps in adequate placental perfusion
  • Option B: Decreased venous pressure: Pressure of the gravid uterus on the IVC primarily leads to reduced venous return to the heart and supine hypotension syndrome. It does contribute to peripheral edema but is not the primary reason.
  • Option C: Increases plasma oncotic pressure: The plasma oncotic pressure is decreased in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary physiological change in pregnancy contributing to peripheral edema is increased capillary permeability. Hormones like progesterone and estrogen cause the dilation of small blood vessels and increased capillary permeability. This allows for the escape of fluid and proteins into the extracellular space, leading to edema, particularly in the lower extremities.

 

Ref: Page No 55, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Uterine compression of the bladder
Decreased blood flow to the kidneys

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, who is 12 weeks pregnant, complains of frequent urination and a sensation of urinary urgency. Which of the following physiological changes in pregnancy is primarily responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Uterine compression of the bladder

 

  • The frequent urination and urinary urgency experienced by the pregnant woman are primarily due to uterine compression of the bladder. As the uterus enlarges and presses against the bladder, it reduces the bladder's capacity, leading to increased urinary frequency.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Elevated GFR:  This leads to a fall in creatinine levels during pregnancy
  • Option C: Decreased blood flow to kidneys: Blood flow to kidneys is increased
  • Option D: Increased ADH secretion: This leads to water retention

 

Educational Objective:

 

The frequent urination and urinary urgency experienced by the pregnant woman are primarily due to uterine compression of the bladder. As the uterus enlarges and presses against the bladder, it reduces the bladder's capacity, leading to increased urinary frequency.

 

 

Ref: Page No 68 , William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system

questions.text: During pregnancy, the maternal cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to support the growing fetus. Which of the following adaptations is a physiological change unique to pregnancy that contributes to maintaining systemic blood pressure and uteroplacental perfusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system

 

  •  During pregnancy, the maternal cardiovascular system undergoes significant changes to support the growing fetus.
  • One of these adaptations is the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.
  • This activation helps maintain systemic blood pressure and uteroplacental perfusion.
  • It increases the retention of sodium and water, leading to expanded plasma volume and ensuring an adequate blood supply to the placenta and fetus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Increased systemic vascular resistance: Vascular resistance is decreased in pregnancy

 

Option B: Elevated maternal Hb: Maternal Hb is reduced in pregnancy

 

Option C: Decreased cardiac output: Cardiac output is increased in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increase

 

Heart rate

 

Stroke volume

 

Cardiac output

 

Blood, red blood cell, and plasma volume

 

Decrease

 

Systemic vascular resistance

 

Systolic, diastolic, and mean arterial pressure

 

Unchanged

 

Central venous pressure

 

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure

 

Left ventricular ejection fraction

 

Left ventricular diastolic function

 

Troponin I

 

Brain natriuretic peptide

 

Ref: Page No 63, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition
